course_title: Contested Peace: Critical Concepts in Peace and Conflict Studies

learning_outcomes.description: Interrogate and articulate the contested, complex nature of core concepts in peace and conflict integrating diverse theoretical perspectives.
Make oral arguments applying core concepts within peace and conflict studies, explicitly addressing underlying power dynamics, normative assumptions, and ethical dilemmas.
Produce quality research analysing contemporary conflicts using core concepts from the course, evaluating how different conceptualizations inform or hinder effective peace processes.

Develop capabilities in using Artificial Intelligence (AI) as a research and analytical tool in peace and conflict studies, as well as analysing its output for theoretical and empirical limitations and biases.
Engage in aesthetic and experiential learning to analyse the contested role of culture in peace and conflict studies.

assessments.task_description:
The Seminar Participation mark is based on your attendance and active participation in seminar discussions, activities, and notetaking, with 2% awarded for each week of active participation in the seminar. The Seminar Participation mark is also based on your engagement with group discussions of Case Study Presentations, asking questions and making comments on others’ Case Study Presentations.

Please note: Preparation in advance for each seminar-- especially covering the required readings (and the background readings if you need to) AND preparing notes on each seminar question for each topic - will make for better and engaging discussions. These discussions are an invaluable opportunity to engage constructively and respectfully with others in the group. Seminars also provide an opportunity to address any specific questions that you may have about the readings and / or topic more generally

You may use AI during seminars, however, in our discussions, if you are drawing on AI, you should inform your peers and your instructor.

assessments.task_description:
The Case Study Presentation is a presentation to the whole class by a group of students in which they present an empirical discussion of a conflict case study, and apply one of the concepts covered in the course to the case study.

The Case Study Presentation will proceed in several steps:

· Each student needs to form a group of two or three members (Week 1)

· Each group needs to pick a CONCEPT and a CASE STUDY from our lists of concepts and case studies developed in the Week 1 seminar.

· Each group needs to choose two readings for the class to read and send them to Melissa one week before their presentation on Monday. For example, if you have a group presentation on 11 August, you need to send the two readings on 4 August.

Each group will have 10 minutes per person to present (20 – 30 minutes in total, depending on the number of group members).

You may use PowerPoint.

Each person will present for 10 minutes (timed).

The presentation should use the questions on the case study worksheet as a guide for their presentations: 

POLS7512 Case Study Worksheet

1. What are the major background factors in your chosen case study?

2. How does concept of ‘X’ relate to your chosen case? (e.g., how is it ‘in play’ or mobilized by key actors?)

3. How does X enable or undermine the search for (or work of) building peace your chosen case?

4. What does X help us to understand about your chosen case?

5. What does X help us to understand about efforts to resolve conflict or build peace in your chosen case?

6. What unresolved puzzles does the application of concept X to your chosen case generate for you?

It is up to the group to decide the order of speakers and how you will engage with the questions. 

The presentation is worth 30 percent of your grade. This is divided into 18 marks for the quality of the group’s presentation, and 12 marks for your individual section of the presentation.

The rubric for assessing the presentation is on the Blackboard.

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

assessments.task_description:
This assessment task develops your skills in curating material, using Artificial Intelligence, and critically evaluating the results produced by AI. It is worth 16% of your grade and assessed using the rubric provided in Blackboard that includes attention to your identification and use quality sources, your curation of quality sources, and your assessment of the quality of empirical and theoretical analysis performed by AI. Your AI research assistant will serve as a resource supporting your study in the course. AI should be considered less as a one-shot solution and instead as a collaborative, back-and-forth tool (C. Jackson & Philips, 2025)

Each student will need to create a free account with a research assistant capable AI (Co-Pilot)

Each student will research and select sources to upload in PDF format to the language model (LM), naming each source uploaded as AuthorLastName_Brief Title_Year (50 sources max).

Students are reminded to ensure their assessment complies with copyright and licensing requirements. This assessment is designed to support critical engagement with AI tools in an ethical and responsible manner. Students are expected to upload documents that are licensed under a creative commons licence.

The submission for the assessment has three parts, and should be a word document submitted through the Turnitin link on Blackboard, comprising:

·        A share link to the LM able to be accessed by melissa.johnston@uq.edu.au

·        A 1000-word literature review, which is a summary of the literature you have collected generated through your engagement with the LM using prompts and refinements and edited and refined by you. This should include a brief section (100-200 words) justifying your selection criteria for these sources. Why these particular 50? How do they represent different facets of a topic, theoretical perspectives, or empirical evidence relevant to the course?

·        A 500-word critical reflection on what the LM did well how it helped you, and a critique identifying the most significant empirical and theoretical weaknesses of the LMs Literature Review. In the theoretical weaknesses, you can include potential sociocultural biases, and how these biases manifest in the summary, and what implications they have for understanding our concepts and cases. In the empirical weaknesses, this can include scrutiny of the AI-generated summary for "hallucinations" (invented information, non-existent facts, or fake sources) 

·        An AI Use Appendix, detailing a step-by-step list of all the tasks and prompts, with a brief summary of why you chose specific prompts, how you refined them, and what changes in AI output resulted from these refinement

For conscientious objectors to AI, the alternative assessment is an annotated bibliography of at least 15 works on a particular concept covering theoretical as well as empirical work.

Artificial Intelligence and Machine Translation are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI/MT in completing this assessment task. Students much clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the student code of conduct.

assessments.assessment_title: Research Essay (3500 words, not including references or appendices).
assessments.task_description:
The research essay is an extended, argument based answer to a single question. It is expected to be 3500 words, not including the bibliography and AI use appendix.

You are expected to develop your own essay topic and then write an essay in an argumentative essay format. The language use should be formal and academic. It is a research essay, so we expect you to draw on peer reviewed and primary sources outside of the course content, however, in this course we expect you to engage fully with concepts and ideas in the recommended and background reading provided in POLS7512.

The essay should be concise and factual, use active voice, and have a clear structure with a logical flow. Please see the marking rubric in Blackboard for more details. It should not use headings for sections in a research essay, instead, organise your content in an introduction, body, and conclusion. Please consult the POLSIS Essay Guide for more information on essay writing.

Artificial intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task.

Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance.

You must provide a step-by-step list of all the tasks and prompts you undertook with AI, including the type of AI used, included as an AI Use Appendix to the Research Essay.

A failure to adequately reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. 

Oral Interview (Hurdle Test)

Students will be interviewed for 5-10 minutes about the argument that they made in their essay with a focus on the ingredients, i.e. the theory, concepts, sources, and on how the argument works. The Interview will be recorded.

Week 13. Date and time determined by sign-up (see Blackboard-Assessment for the link to the sign-up document). The student’s assigned timeslot will be considered the due date and time for this hurdle.

This Oral Interview assesses the Learning Outcomes embodied in the essay. Eloquence, or the delivery of the answers, does not affect the mark.

learning_activities.topic:
Introduction - Why Contested Peace?

First, this week introduces and elaborates on the course description, and the course coordinator will explain the course rationale, teaching and learning style, and the concepts to be covered. We will briefly consider, for instance, why it is necessary and important to examine key concepts, the relationship between theory and practice, and how the subfields of conflict resolution and peacebuilding are positioned in relation to broader fields of political science and international studies.

Second, this seminar will deliberate and decide upon the conflict case studies we will examine for the semester. This includes the option for you to propose particular cases you are interested in,

Third, this seminar will deliberate and decide upon group composition for group presentations. That will involve choosing group members, and choosing which concept from the five available the group wants to address.

learning_activities.topic:
Conceptual Discussions: The State

This week considers "the idea of the state" by asking: "When and what are states? We start engaging with the diverse definitions of the state by first thinking about historical perspectives. Then we use different theoretical lenses to explore definitional components of the state? What are key contending perspectives on the state? Finally, we encourage students to reflect on what is at stake in different perspectives and approaches to the state, especially in peacebuilding and conflict resolution?"

The concept of the state is "essentially contested" and lacks an "agreed concept" or "essence or natural boundaries"(Skinner, 2010). We moved beyond pluralist views, like Robert Dahl's notion of the state as a neutral arena for competing interests, to consider more dynamic perspectives. In our discussion, we will use a variety of theoretical perspectives this week to discuss The State. We begin our process by historicising the state, and then probe its meaning and implications using Realist, Weberian, Marxist, Feminist and Post-structural perspectives. The core question for peacebuilding remains: how do these differing conceptions of the state enable or undermine constructive engagement with conflicts and the pursuit of peace.

Case Study Presentations: The State

In week 3, we engage with the concept of the 'state' in conflict resolution and peacebuilding practice though case examples. Our goal here is to critically examine how the 'state', including differing conceptions of it, enable or undermines the process of engaging constructively with conflicts and building peace.

The seminar will involve student Case Study Presentations in which students apply the concept of “The State” to a case study of conflict. This will be followed by a Q&A session with the student presenters, moderated by the Course Coordinator, and then a general discussion.

learning_activities.topic:
Conceptual Discussions: Interests

We consider the idea of 'interests' this week. Interests figure in much thinking and practice in the field of conflict resolution and peacebuilding. Conflict is often defined, for instance, as a clash of interests. These interests may be categorised as political, economic, cultural, social, national, or religious. We unpack this concept through available definitions, the ideas and practices that are often associated with it, the tensions and contestations it generates, and how these tensions and contestations inform the field of peace and conflict resolution

A focus on interests can both illuminate and constrain approaches to peacebuilding and conflict resolution in diverse contexts. On one hand, such contexts are sites for enunciating, reshaping and structuring socio-political forces as part of peacebuilding and political ordering. The idea of interests can help to map conflict dynamics and forge possible agreements. On the other hand, the understanding of interests that peacebuilding and conflict resolution intervenors deploy can profoundly influence how socio-political reshaping and structuring occurs, and the form of the resulting peace.

learning_activities.topic:
No Seminar: Reading Week

Learning outcomes: L01, L03

Conceptual Discussions: Sovereignty, Guest Lecture.

The aim this week  is to achieve an informed overview of the concept and its usage to form a foundation upon which we can engage with the concept of sovereignty in peacebuilding and conflict resolution. Our guiding questions include: What is sovereignty? This includes: What are the definitional elements associated with sovereignty?) What are key contending perspectives on sovereignty? What is at stake in different perspectives and approaches to sovereignty?

Sovereignty is the foundational concept of modern international relations, establishing national governments as supreme authorities within their territories and implying non-interference in internal affairs, thereby defining states as primary global actors. Historically, the concept has evolved from a "principle" to a fundamental "right" of peoples, particularly in decolonization contexts, yet its precise legal and political scope remains unclear and contested. This ambiguity arises partly from its deep link to territorial integrity, which can complicate self-determination claims beyond traditional colonial situations.

learning_activities.topic:
Conceptual Discussions: Power

The idea of power occupies a central place in political science scholarship and political practice, and awareness of it is crucial for the practice of peacebuilding and conflict resolution. However, power often remains a vague and confusing notion, including in peace and conflict studies. This week follows the pattern established thus far - we consider key definitional questions and different approaches to the concept.

Rather than offering a singular, definitive understanding, our focus is on appreciating the multifaceted nature of power and the academic debates that continuously reshape its meaning and application. However, disciplining discussions often privilege only one form of power, thereby overlooking its diverse manifestations and failing to develop sophisticated understandings of how global outcomes are produced and how actors are enabled and constrained (Barnett & Duvall, 2005). Therefore, this week encourages students to move beyond simplistic interpretations and engage with power's polymorphous character to deepen their theoretical understanding of international politics.

learning_activities.topic:
Case Study Presentations: Power

This week continues the pattern of examining how a key concept resonates in peacebuilding and conflict resolution practice. We ask a range of questions, including: What happens when multiple and conflicting conceptions of power are at play in a given conflict situation? How should conflict resolution and peacebuilding practitioners analyse power to maximise the effectiveness of their practice? What understandings of power best serve conflict resolution and peacebuilding practice.

The seminar will involve student Case Study Presentations in which students apply the concept of “power” to a case study of conflict. This will be followed by a Q&A session with the student presenters, moderated by the Course Coordinator, and then a general discussion.

learning_activities.topic:
Conceptual Discussions: Culture

This week we will be visiting the exhibition Suna (middle ground) by Yuriyal Bridgeman at the UQ Art Museum. The first part of the seminar will include a curatorial presentation at the art museum, followed by a Q&A session.

The second part of the seminar will be our seminar discussion on the concept of culture in peacebuilding, but will take place inside the exhibition space. A range of fields have experienced a cultural turn in recent decades. Peace and conflict resolution is no exception. This week we analyse culture as a fluid and contested concept that is open to varied interpretations. The goal is to assess how these contestations inform, challenge and transform the place of culture in peace and conflict resolution. We critically examine contemporary possibilities for responding to cultural difference in the field of conflict resolution and peacebuilding. We following the pattern established thus far in the course, beginning by analysing the contested definitions of culture, and the interpretations and paradoxes that underlie these definitions.

learning_activities.topic:
Course Review

In our final conceptual discussion, Week 13: Course Review, we pause to reflect on the complex, contested, and often hidden dimensions of peace and conflict that have been central to POLS7512, "Contested Peace: Critical Concepts in Peace and Conflict". Our journey has been an intensive investigation of core concepts, deliberately embracing the "definitional chaos" and "essentially contested nature" of terms like the state, interests, sovereignty, power, and culture. This week is designed to foster a summative understanding, allowing you to gauge your grasp of the academic debates over these five concepts and their profound relevance to peace and conflict studies.
